title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 07
author: Various
snippet: Before me, and stretching far southward, thedistant Criffell, lumbering on the horizon; the sunny Solway, gleamingin light; the Nith, winding and coqueting with its fertile banks andfruitful plains; the Annan, a younger but scarcely less lovely sister,running its lateral course to the same ultimate destiny, the nascentfeeders of the Clyde, Carsehope, and Darr, bursting from their mossycradles into the wilderness around them, rejoicing in their solitudes,and in their numerous and undisturbed inmates.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 07
author: Various
snippet: This sailor, whosename was Bill Wilson, and whose trade in his old age was that ofsmuggling tea and brandy from the Solway to the Clyde, used to fill hishead with adventure, and daring purpose, and successful execution.

title: The Lilac Sunbonnet: A Love Story
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: It was in the bright morning light that these two took theEdinburgh road, which clambered down over the hillsides by thevillage of Leadhills into the valley of the Clyde.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: He purposed that we should go up Tweed to a hiding-place whichhe knew of on the Cor Water, and then make over by the upper waters ofthe Clyde and the Abington moors to the house of Smitwood.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: At Crossford, where the Nethan meets theClyde, I met a man who had been to the salmon-fishing and had caught abig salmon-trout; and as I looked, my old love for the sport awokewithin me, and I longed to feel a rod in my hand.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: As I rode along thegreen sward by the side of Clyde, the larks were singing in the sky andthe trout were plashing in the waters, and all the world was gay.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I didnot fling my books into the Clyde as at first I proposed, but leftinjunctions that they were to be sent by the carrier.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: By Heaven, I would make an end of this; I wouldget me home without delay; I would fling my books into the Clyde; Iwould go to the wars; I would be a great cavalier, and, by the Lord, Iwould keep up the name of the house!  I was astonished myself at thesudden change in my feelings, for in the space of some ten minutes awhole age had passed for me, and I had grown from a boy to some measureof manhood.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Thence the next day Irode to Hamilton and in the evening came to the bridge of the Clyde atGlasgow.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The air was keen and frosty, and I rode in high fettle by thetowns of Biggar and Lanark to the valley of the Clyde.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: "If so happen we get Mistress Marjory safe," saidI, "you will ride off with her without delay, down the valley to theClyde and then straight towards Tweeddale.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: But stay, are these not the hills of Kilpatrick, which stretchdown from the Lennox to the Clyde and front the river at this veryDumbarton?

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I was stillin doubt of his purpose, whether he was bound for his own house ofEaglesham or for the more distant Clyde coast.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: But here we did not stay, being eager to win to ourjourney's end; so after a glass of wine at an inn we took the paththrough the now dusky meadows by Clyde side, and passing through thevillage of Gorbals, which lies on the south bank of the river, wecrossed the great bridge and entered the gates just as they were on thepoint of closing.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: So in this way we talked till we came to where the road leaves the Clydevalley and rises steep to the high land about the town of Hamilton.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: So off he set and came to this inn of the Clyde fords, and then he heardthat on the evening before such a cavalcade had passed as he sought.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I had never seen the soldiers before, but I made a guess that they weredisbanded men of my cousin's company, both from their air of exceedingbraggadocio which clung to all who had any relation to Gilbert Burnet,and also since there were no soldiers in this special part of the Clydedale save his.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Here I left the stream side and struck into thecountry, whence I returned again nearly opposite the town of Lanark, atthe broad, shallow place in the river, which folk call the Fords o'Clyde.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The dull November eve came on me ere I reached the Clyde.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: In such wild fashion I rodeover the low haughlands of Clyde, and forded the river at a deep placewhere it flowed still and treacherous among reeds, never heeding, butswimming my horse across, though I had enough to do to land on the otherside.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Straight down from it one looks on the steep braes of Kirkfieldbank andthe bridge which the Romans built over the river; and even there themurmur of the great falls in Clyde comes to a man's ear.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Far on all sides I had a view of the wide landscape, from therugged high hills of Tweeddale and the upper Clyde to the lowlands inthe west which stretch to Glasgow and the sea.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The entranceto the town was down a steep path from the moor, for the place is builtabove the gorge of Clyde, yet something lower than the surroundingmoorlands.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: We were passing under the great mass of Tintock--a high,hump-backed hill which rises sheer from the level land and stands like amighty sentinel o'er the upper Clyde valley.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The place was watched most jealously,for Holmes Mill was there, and the junction of the roads to the upperTweed and the moors of Clyde.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: In such afashion, half-creeping, half running, I made my way down the hills whichflank the Coulter Water, and came at length to the range of low hillswhich look down upon Biggar and the lowlands of Clyde.

author: Buchan, John
snippet: Or maybe they had gone up the water on their way to the moorsof Clyde.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Keep awa' frae the Clydehills for ony sake, for they're lookit like my ain hill i' the lambin'time; and though it's maybe safer there for ye the noo, in a wee it'llbe het eneuch.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: By this time I was on a little plateau, near the great black hill ofCoomb Dod, a place whence three streams flow--the Camps Water and theCoulter Water to the Clyde, and the burn of Kingledoors to Tweed.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I am Tweedside born and will own noallegiance save to my own fair river, but I will grant that next to itthere is none fairer than the upper Clyde.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: In less than an hour I had turned a corner of hill and there before melay the noble strath of Clyde.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Here I turned from the path, for I had no desire to go to Abington, andstruck up a narrow howe in the hills, which from the direction I guessedmust lead to the lower Clyde.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Now I dared not go back to Tweeddale by the way by which I had come, forthe Clyde valley above Abington would be a hunting-ground of dragoonsfor many days.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: And now we were climbing the long range which flanks the Potrail Water,which is the larger of the twin feeders of Clyde.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: To the right lay Abington and the lowerClyde valley, where my sweet cousin and his men held goodly fellowship.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: We kept over the rocky ravine through which the little river Evan flowsto Annan, and came to the wide moorlands which stretch about the upperstreams of Clyde.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Now it wouldhave been both easier and quieter to have ridden down the broad, lowglen of the Medlock Water, which flows into Clyde by the village ofCrawford.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Soon we had climbed the low range which separates the Clyde glen fromthe Tweed and turned down the narrow ravine of the burn which I thinkthey call Fopperbeck, and which flows into the Evan Water.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I knew that the two dragoons had ridden straight down the Cor Waterglen, making for the upper vale of Tweed and thence to the Clyde hills.

title: The Importance of Being Seven
author: McCall Smith, Alexander

title: Sunny memories of foreign lands.
author: Stowe, Harriet Beecher
snippet: Nevertheless, when we came to the arbor which commanded  the finest view of the old castle, and saw its gray, ivy- clad walls, standing forth on a beautiful point, round which swept the brown, dimpling waves of the Clyde, the indescribable  sweetness, sadness, wUdness of the whole scene would make its voice heard in our hearts.

snippet: Bothwell's lord was the lord of this castle, whose beautiful ruins here adorn the banks of the Clyde.

snippet: As we stood on the bridge with the noisy, shallow waters of the Clyde rolling underneath us and contemplated the picturesque surroundings, we were carried back in imagination to that fatal day in June, 1679, when the Covenanters under Balfour of Burley, Hackston and others, faced the army under the Duke of Monmouth and his savage lieutenants, Claverhouse and Dalzell.

title: From Occident to Orient.

title: A holiday tour in Europe.
